head.title: Why People Resist Higher Gas Taxes

hedline.hl1: Why People Resist Higher Gas Taxes

abstract.p: Steven DeMaio letter on Thomas L Friedman's March 1 Op-Ed says higher gas tax will be palatable once Americans are made to realize that driving less is patriotic

block.p: Re ''Who's Afraid of a Gas Tax?,'' by Thomas L. Friedman (column, March 1):
Re ''Who's Afraid of a Gas Tax?,'' by Thomas L. Friedman (column, March 1):
The wisdom of Mr. Friedman's call for a higher gas tax as part of a patriotic national strategy to achieve energy and climate security is obvious. Unfortunately, not all the groundwork has been laid.

Americans first need to understand that simply driving less is patriotic. Once walking, biking and taking the bus have been cast as acts of patriotism, it will be much easier to frame a tax on driving as patriotic. Our leaders, sadly, have not yet delivered the message, ''Here's what you can do today to make our nation more secure.''

We need investment in renewable energy now, and we needed a gas tax yesterday. But let's not underestimate the need for the long-overdue first step of empowering citizens through direct, daily, individual participation in energy reform.
